What is Verus's Public Blockchains as a Service (PBaaS) and how does it enable users to create their own customizable blockchains?

Verus's Public Blockchains as a Service (PBaaS) is a feature that allows anyone to create their own independent and customizable blockchain. To create a chain, one needs to have a VerusID name for the chain. This means that users can launch their own blockchains with ease, and each blockchain in the ecosystem is independent and customizable.

One of the key benefits of PBaaS is that chains can be nested to any level, allowing for an unlimited number of new chains to be spawned from a single chain. For example, a chain called "NewChain" can be launched on the main Verus blockchain, and then NewChain can be used to launch an unlimited number of new chains, each using identities on NewChain.

Newly created chains inherit the 50/50% PoW/PoS consensus mechanism, which may be customizable in the future. Additionally, a newly created chain can be mined by the miners of VerusCoin, thanks to a feature called Merge-Mining. This means that a creator of a chain doesn't have to worry about creating their own mining infrastructure, as they can tap into the existing mining power of VerusCoin.

PBaaS chains form the basis for a practically unlimited scalability of the Verus system. This is because popular currencies and tokens can exist and be interchangeable on many Verus blockchains, so they won't be restricted or limited by the capacities of a single blockchain.

When creating a chain, the creator has a range of options to customize the chain's characteristics. For example, they can specify coin supply, coin emission with up to three eras, and define the price for identities. They can also set up Kickstarter-like minimums to activate the chain, or automatically refund if the minimums are not met. Other options include dynamic coin launch pricing based on participation, pre-launch participation price discounts, pre-conversion reserve currency carve outs, and price-neutral launch pre-allocations. All of these options can be specified using easy-to-understand commands and parameters, without requiring any programming knowledge.
